update.description:
- modified the polyline extrusion implementation to perform delaunay triangluation on paths (polylines) that consist of exterior edges and holes inside.

- support parsing repeated <polyline> elements in Visual and PolylineShape

- add tests

The idea is to parse polylines in an svg file and and extrude a 3D mesh from it
update.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

content.raw: Thanks for the clarification. One possibility with multiple heights would be to support partially drilled holes in a surface, but that's pretty complicated. It would probably be easier to split the collision into two separate shapes with mating faces: one with a drilled hole and one without.
content.html: Thanks for the clarification. One possibility with multiple heights would be to support partially drilled holes in a surface, but that's pretty complicated. It would probably be easier to split the collision into two separate shapes with mating faces: one with a drilled hole and one without.

pull_request.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

pullrequest.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

content.raw:
I updated the documentation in c6a724b.

There will only be one height which applies to all polylines. We thought about changing the way we describe a polyline in SDF to allow us to specify holes in the polyline shape, and in the end we came up with just letting users specify multiple polylines.  We then implemented a ray casting algorithm to automatically find out which polylines form the exterior and interior edges of the polyline shape, see [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1428/support-mesh-extrusion-from-polylines-that/diff#Lgazebo/common/GTSMeshUtils.ccT101). We decided to go with this option as the change doesn't break the SDF spec and we won't need to release another SDF version.
content.html:
I updated the documentation in c6a724b.

There will only be one height which applies to all polylines. We thought about changing the way we describe a polyline in SDF to allow us to specify holes in the polyline shape, and in the end we came up with just letting users specify multiple polylines. We then implemented a ray casting algorithm to automatically find out which polylines form the exterior and interior edges of the polyline shape, see here. We decided to go with this option as the change doesn't break the SDF spec and we won't need to release another SDF version.

pull_request.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

pullrequest.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

content.raw:
I have a question about the change in the polyline data structure. The `geometry.proto` message is changing the polyline from `optional` to `repeated`. Since the `polyline.proto` message declares both `height` and `vertices` fields, this means that a polyline message will have multiple height values specified. Also the `polyline.world` has multiple `polyline` geometry elements.

The `PolylineShape` API's are changing to allow multiple sets of vertices, but not multiple height values. Do we need multiple height values?

Also, how are multiple sets of vertices interpreted? Is the first always a solid shape and any following sets of vertices will subtract? This should be clarified in the documentation.
content.html:
I have a question about the change in the polyline data structure. The geometry.proto message is changing the polyline from optional to repeated. Since the polyline.proto message declares both height and vertices fields, this means that a polyline message will have multiple height values specified. Also the polyline.world has multiple polyline geometry elements.

The PolylineShape API's are changing to allow multiple sets of vertices, but not multiple height values. Do we need multiple height values?

Also, how are multiple sets of vertices interpreted? Is the first always a solid shape and any following sets of vertices will subtract? This should be clarified in the documentation.

content.raw:
I'm having trouble running this on osx. The `UNIT_GTSMeshUtils_TEST` test fails:
~~~
[ RUN      ] GTSMeshUtils.DelaunayTriangulation
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_simbody/src/gazebo/gazebo/common/GTSMeshUtils_TEST.cc:61: Failure
Value of: 8u
  Actual: 8
Expected: subMesh->GetVertexCount()
Which is: 0
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_simbody/src/gazebo/gazebo/common/GTSMeshUtils_TEST.cc:64: Failure
Value of: 8u
  Actual: 8
Expected: subMesh->GetIndexCount() / 3u
Which is: 0
[  FAILED  ] GTSMeshUtils.DelaunayTriangulation (8 ms)
~~~
Also, I see error messages  when I try to load `worlds/polyline.world`:
~~~
[Err] [MeshManager.cc:637] Unable to extrude mesh. Triangulation failed
[Err] [Visual.cc:2271] Unable to insert mesh[Vertex Buffer: Out of memory]
[Err] [MeshManager.cc:637] Unable to extrude mesh. Triangulation failed
[Err] [Visual.cc:2271] Unable to insert mesh[Vertex Buffer: Out of memory]
~~~

~~~
$ brew info gts
gts: stable 0.7.6
http://gts.sourceforge.net/
/usr/local/Cellar/gts/0.7.6 (24 files, 1.3M) *
  Built from source
From: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/blob/master/Library/Formula/gts.rb
==> Dependencies
Build: pkg-config ✔
Required: gettext ✔, glib ✔, netpbm ✔
==> Options
--universal
	Build a universal binary
~~~

pullrequest.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

content.raw:
These new test files need to be wrapped in `if (HAVE_GTS)` like the [other GTS related code](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b473ae65501a2a5bfe6d6510403d0c618dcb306a/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt#cl-94). Otherwise you get [build failures](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/500/) on systems without `libgts-dev` installed.

We can re-run the Jenkins builds once this is fixed. Also @\_jrivero_ , we should consider installing `libgts-dev` in one of the Jenkins jobs. Perhaps the [gazebo-any-dart4 job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/) or the [homebrew job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/)?
content.html:
These new test files need to be wrapped in if (HAVE_GTS) like the other GTS related code. Otherwise you get build failures on systems without libgts-dev installed.

We can re-run the Jenkins builds once this is fixed. Also @_jrivero_ , we should consider installing libgts-dev in one of the Jenkins jobs. Perhaps the gazebo-any-dart4 job or the homebrew job?
